Award.AwardTitle: Support for Doctoral Students to Attend International Conferences: Artificial Intelligence in Education (AIED 2015) and Educational Data Mining Society (EDM 2015)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cyberlearning and Future Learning Technologies Program funds efforts that support envisioning the future of learning technologies and advancing what we know about how people learn in technology-rich environments. Capacity-building (CAP) projects help build the capacity of the field to do high-quality, high-impact research on learning. This project supports the mission of NSF to train more advanced professionals in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) by supporting doctoral students attendance at the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Education (AIED) and the 6th International Conference on Educational Data Mining (EDM) to be held in Madrid, Spain in June of 2015.

The intellectual merit of the grant rests on the quality of the research being presented at the conferences. Together, the conferences provide cross-fertilization of information and ideas from artificial intelligence, cognitive science, machine learning, education, learning sciences, educational technology, psychology, philosophy, sociology, anthropology, linguistics, and the many domain-specific areas for which cyberlearning systems are designed and built. The broader impact of the work rests in the inculcation of students into this field. Doctoral students will be selected from U.S. institutions. The criteria for selection include either having a paper accepted for one of the conferences and/or or submitting an strong rationale for what the student would learn at the conference. All students receiving support will be assigned a mentor. The selecting committee will strive to ensure that there is diversity of institutions, topics, disciplines, ethnicities, and gender in the cohort of awardees. Selected students will receive up to $1,000 to partially cover expenses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project received funding from NSF Cyberlearning to support 18 doctoral students from the United States to attend the 17th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Education held June 22-26, 2015 in Madrid, Spain and/or the co-located 6th International Conference on Educational Data Mining held in Madrid, Spain, June 26-29, 2015.

The PI worked with the Doctoral Consortium 2015 committee to review candidates who would receive NSF travel support. She met with students at the ITS 2015 conference and talked to them about their research and reimbursement of travel expenses. She received summaries of their research and was responsible for all report writing. The PI received no funding from this YRT award.

At the conferences graduate students met with researchers and practitioners to exchange ideas, theories, experiments, techniques, applications and evaluations of initiatives supporting new developments relevant for the future. This AIED 2015 conference offered a professional opportunity for graduate students to present cutting-edge research from the fields of Artificial Intelligence (AI), computer science, cognitive and learning sciences, psychology, and educational technology. Graduate students who were selected to receive NSF funds enjoyed several special sessions to present their research ideas and to receive feedback from researchers in the ITS community. This activity supports the mission of NSF and other granting agencies to train more advanced professionals in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM).

This NSF funding supported 18 advanced doctoral students to attend the two conferences and associated tutorials and workshops associated. The Doctoral Consortium provided a forum in which PhD students presented and discussed their work during its early stages, met peers with related interests, and worked with more senior members of the field (mentors). The program was open to all USA PhD students and invited submissions of papers with advisors or collaborators. The students profited from their experience at the conferences as indicated in their written comments. Summaries for all accepted proposals were published in the conference proceedings and made available on-line through the conference website. Graduate students presented their research to the larger community, spoke individually with leaders in the field and generally received strong support by articulating their research and receiving feedback. Many of these conversations continued later during the year and many mentors have been included on student dissertation committees. NSF funding supported students to become involved in the conference and activities in subsequent years as members of the research community. Students had access to various resources provided to the international members. More young researchers will be actively integrated with the research community as a result of this award.

Nearly 50 papers were presented by these researchers or co-authored by them. NSF funding was reserved for advanced doctoral students, or those who had completed a Master’s degree, undertaken a major interdisciplinary project, and/or had about a year of academic work left to complete prior to defending their dissertation proposal.

This funding contributed to disciplines such as computer science, education and psychology. By clearly identifying and implementing the steps for adaptive teaching, these young researchers have contributed to the cadre of people who can develop intelligent instructional systems. This project also made important contributions to quantitative evaluation. The papers that were accepted for publication often contained very complex and detailed quantitative evaluations that identified which instructional interventions and which environments were effective and for which types of learners.
